results.headline: More Than Words
results.summary_short: In Peter Hanson’s dishy documentary “Tales From the Script,” 46 screenwriters gab agreeably about the tribulations of their profession.

results.headline: Kidnapping Melodrama
results.summary_short: “Stolen” plays like a middling episode of “Law & Order: SVU,” drawn out an extra half-hour.

results.headline: A Marine Searches for Meaning in the Sands and ‘Steel Rain’ of Iraq

results.headline: A Rebel, Brooding and Smoking His Way Out of Bourgeois Normalcy
results.summary_short: In “Remember Me” love means never having to say you’re sorry, particularly to the audience.

results.headline: Walking Down the Comedic Aisle
results.summary_short: “Our Family Wedding” offers plenty that’s old, borrowed and blue; it’s the something new that’s missing.

results.headline: Treading Softly Around a Minefield of Emotions
results.summary_short: “The Exploding Girl” is Bradley Rust Gray’s sweet and tentative new film.

results.headline: Trouble in the Village
results.summary_short: When the liveliest character in a movie is the heroine’s pet turtle, you know you’re in for some seriously stately filmmaking.

results.headline: That American Dream: Scheme and Scramble
results.summary_short: “Children of Invention,” a modestly scaled, quietly effective independent movie about a struggling single mother and her two children.

results.headline: Outside the Abbey’s Fortified Walls, a World of Fairy Girls and Beasts
results.summary_short: “The Secret of Kells” conveys the almost sacred magic of color and line.

results.headline: A Saint Among Sinners, With Operatic Dreams
results.summary_short: “Harlem Aria” is a follow-your-dreams fable of surpassing sentimentality.

results.headline: When Troubled Cops Cross the Thin Blue Line
results.summary_short: “Brooklyn’s Finest” burrows deep into the collective memory of generations of meaty, emotional movies about New York City cops in trouble.

results.headline: Haunted by What Dad Did in the War

results.headline: On a High School Lacrosse Team, Opposites Attract and Attack

results.headline: Learning to Read, Murder, Survive
results.summary_short: “A Prophet” is one of those rare films in which the moral stakes are as insistent and thought through as the aesthetic choices.

results.headline: Family Dynamics

results.headline: Three Loners on a Road Leading to One Another
results.summary_short: William Hurt, who specializes in playing high-strung, upscale neurotics, brings his formidable skills to “The Yellow Handkerchief.”
